<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 415, 275, 431]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 431, 868, 462]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 462, 326, 477]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 477, 364, 492]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 492, 328, 507]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 507, 670, 523]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 565, 391, 581]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 581, 442, 597]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 597, 569, 613]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 851, 89]]<|/det|> Which instrument is most suitable for measuring the thickness of a single sheet of paper? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 138, 117]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 100, 240, 117]]<|/det|> 15 cm rule <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 133, 144]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 125, 222, 144]]<|/det|> balance <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 133, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 152, 240, 170]]<|/det|> metre rule <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 133, 196]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 178, 359, 196]]<|/det|> micrometer screw gauge <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 94, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 222, 594, 241]]<|/det|> The diagrams show distance–time graphs for four objects. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 682, 271]]<|/det|> Which graph represents an object moving with an increasing speed? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 279, 781, 630]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 660, 97, 679]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 660, 878, 679]]<|/det|> An object has a weight of \(6.4 \text{N}\) on the Earth where the gravitational field strength is \(10 \text{N / kg}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 691, 920, 724]]<|/det|> Which row states the mass and the weight of the object on the Moon where the gravitational field strength is \(1.6 \text{N / kg}\)? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 734, 477, 880]]<|/det|>
mass / kgweight on the Moon / N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 691, 97, 710]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 691, 707, 710]]<|/det|> A spring, which obeys Hooke's law, has an unstretched length of \(10 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 721, 485, 740]]<|/det|> A load of \(20 \text{N}\) is suspended from the spring. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 752, 430, 770]]<|/det|> The new length of the spring is \(36 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 781, 477, 800]]<|/det|> What is the spring constant \(k\) of the spring? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 810, 134, 828]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 810, 245, 828]]<|/det|> 0.56 N/ cm <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 810, 303, 828]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 810, 411, 828]]<|/det|> 0.77 N/ cm <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 810, 470, 828]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 810, 566, 828]]<|/det|> 1.3 N/ cm <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 810, 636, 828]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 810, 734, 828]]<|/det|> 1.8 N/ cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 922, 106]]<|/det|> What is the relationship between the impulse acting on an object and the change in momentum of the object? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 114, 133, 131]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 114, 420, 133]]<|/det|> impulse = change in momentum <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 141, 133, 159]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 141, 475, 160]]<|/det|> impulse = change in momentum \(\times\) time <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 175, 133, 193]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 168, 425, 195]]<|/det|> impulse = \(\frac{\text{change in momentum}}{\text{time}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 220, 133, 240]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 214, 425, 240]]<|/det|> impulse = \(\frac{\text{change in momentum}}{\text{mass}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 276, 96, 294]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 276, 569, 295]]<|/det|> Electrical energy may be obtained from nuclear fission. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 307, 576, 325]]<|/det|> In which order is the energy transferred in this process? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 336, 133, 355]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 336, 660, 355]]<|/det|> nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) turbines <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 363, 133, 381]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 363, 660, 381]]<|/det|> nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) turbines \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 390, 133, 409]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 390, 660, 408]]<|/det|> nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) turbines <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 418, 133, 437]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 418, 660, 437]]<|/det|> nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) turbines \(\rightarrow\) generator <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 462, 96, 481]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 462, 922, 495]]<|/det|> A motor of power \(P\) exerts a force \(F\) on an object. The object moves a distance \(d\) during the time \(t\) that the force acts. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 507, 504, 526]]<|/det|> Which equation is used to calculate the time \(t\) ? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 536, 133, 555]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 536, 210, 555]]<|/det|> \(t = \frac{F}{Pd}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 536, 298, 555]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 536, 376, 555]]<|/det|> \(t = \frac{Fd}{P}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 536, 466, 555]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 536, 546, 555]]<|/det|> \(t = \frac{Pd}{F}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[613, 536, 633, 555]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[645, 536, 715, 555]]<|/det|> $t = \frac{P}{Fd}$ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 593, 104, 611]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 592, 787, 611]]<|/det|> A scientist uses an electric motor to lift a load through a vertical distance of 2.0 m. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 624, 912, 657]]<|/det|> He then increases the input power to the motor and repeats the experiment. The efficiency of the motor does not change. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 669, 910, 702]]<|/det|> Which row correctly describes the effect that this has on the useful work done lifting the load and the time taken to lift it? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 714, 551, 842]]<|/det|>
work donetime taken
Adecreasesdecreases
Bstays the samedecreases
Cdecreasesstays the same
Dstays the samestays the same

<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 897, 89]]<|/det|>
Four containers are filled to the top with the same liquid. The base of each container is circular.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 740, 120]]<|/det|>
Which container has the greatest pressure exerted by the liquid at its base?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 131, 201, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 158, 868, 272]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 299, 106, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 299, 504, 317]]<|/det|>
A liquid is evaporating. The liquid is not boiling.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 329, 646, 346]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the liquid is correct at an instant in time?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 357, 134, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 357, 628, 375]]<|/det|>
Any molecule can escape, and from any part of the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 383, 133, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 383, 648, 401]]<|/det|>
Any molecule can escape, but only from the liquid's surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 410, 131, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 410, 834, 427]]<|/det|>
Only molecules with enough energy can escape, and only from the liquid's surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 435, 133, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 435, 804, 453]]<|/det|>
Only molecules with enough energy can escape, but from any part of the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 479, 106, 497]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 479, 761, 497]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows two cylinders connected by a narrow tube fitted with a tap.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 504, 688, 567]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 581, 920, 615]]<|/det|>
One cylinder contains \(80 \text{cm}^3\) of gas at a pressure of \(2.0 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\). The other cylinder contains a vacuum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 626, 920, 660]]<|/det|>
The volume of the evacuated cylinder is \(20 \text{cm}^3\). The tap is opened so that the gas can flow to fill both cylinders.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 672, 494, 689]]<|/det|>
The temperature of the gas remains constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 701, 425, 719]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 731, 134, 749]]<|/det|>

0.50 × 10⁵Pa

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 758, 133, 777]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 758, 255, 777]]<|/det|>
1.6 × 10⁵Pa

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 787, 133, 804]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 787, 255, 804]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 455, 89]]<|/det|> An aluminium block has a mass of \(200 \text{g}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 581, 121]]<|/det|> The specific heat capacity of aluminium is \(900 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \circ \text{C})\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 133, 868, 152]]<|/det|> How much energy is needed to increase the temperature of the block from \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(110^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 609, 89]]<|/det|> The diagram shows waves in a ripple tank containing water. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 98, 616, 214]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 225, 695, 243]]<|/det|> The waves approach a barrier and pass through the gap in the barrier. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 255, 737, 273]]<|/det|> The size of the gap is about the same size as the wavelength of the ripples. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 286, 336, 304]]<|/det|> The gap size is increased. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 317, 618, 335]]<|/det|> What happens to the ripple pattern to the right of the barrier? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 344, 134, 363]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 344, 411, 363]]<|/det|> The ripples are closer together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 371, 133, 390]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 371, 391, 390]]<|/det|> The ripples are further apart. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 397, 133, 416]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 397, 393, 415]]<|/det|> The ripples are more curved. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 424, 133, 443]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 424, 384, 442]]<|/det|> The ripples are less curved. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 467, 106, 486]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 467, 348, 486]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a wave. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 495, 771, 625]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 638, 752, 656]]<|/det|> Which row correctly indicates the amplitude and the wavelength of the wave? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 668, 719, 797]]<|/det|>
amplitudewavelength
Athe distance between 1 and 2the distance between 4 and 5
Bthe distance between 1 and 2the distance between 4 and 6
Cthe distance between 1 and 3the distance between 4 and 5
Dthe distance between 1 and 3the distance between 4 and 6

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> Two beams of light are both the same colour of red. One beam is travelling through air. The other beam is travelling through water. Each beam has a different brightness. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 116, 537, 135]]<|/det|> Which quantity is the same for both sets of waves? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 145, 138, 163]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 145, 237, 163]]<|/det|> amplitude <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 171, 138, 189]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 171, 237, 189]]<|/det|> frequency <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 197, 138, 215]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 197, 207, 215]]<|/det|> speed <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 223, 138, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 223, 250, 240]]<|/det|> wavelength <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 268, 106, 286]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 266, 920, 301]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a ray of light in air incident on a glass block. Some of the light is refracted and some of the light is reflected. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 645, 107, 664]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 645, 868, 664]]<|/det|> Which list shows regions of the electromagnetic spectrum in order of increasing frequency? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 675, 134, 693]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 675, 520, 693]]<|/det|> X-ray \(\rightarrow\) ultraviolet \(\rightarrow\) visible light \(\rightarrow\) infrared <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 702, 134, 720]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 702, 520, 720]]<|/det|> X-ray \(\rightarrow\) infrared \(\rightarrow\) visible light \(\rightarrow\) ultraviolet <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 730, 134, 749]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 730, 520, 749]]<|/det|> infrared \(\rightarrow\) visible light \(\rightarrow\) ultraviolet \(\rightarrow\) X-ray <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 758, 134, 776]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 758, 520, 776]]<|/det|> ultraviolet \(\rightarrow\) visible light \(\rightarrow\) infrared \(\rightarrow\) X-ray <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 802, 107, 821]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 802, 284, 821]]<|/det|> What is ultrasound? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 831, 134, 848]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 831, 675, 848]]<|/det|> sound waves that are so loud that they damage human hearing <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 857, 134, 875]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 857, 630, 875]]<|/det|> sound waves that are too high-pitched for humans to hear <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 884, 134, 902]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 884, 623, 902]]<|/det|> sound waves that are too low-pitched for humans to hear <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 910, 134, 928]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 910, 569, 927]]<|/det|> sound waves that are too quiet for humans to hear

Two resistors, with resistances \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\), are connected in parallel.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 541, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 233, 534, 252]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 261, 134, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 261, 354, 280]]<|/det|>
less than either \(R_{1}\) or \(R_{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 288, 134, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 288, 247, 306]]<|/det|>
equal to \(R_{1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 314, 134, 333]]<|/det|>

equal to \(R_{2}\)

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 341, 361, 358]]<|/det|>
the average of \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 384, 106, 403]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 384, 709, 403]]<|/det|>
The metal cases of electrical appliances are connected to an earth wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 414, 384, 433]]<|/det|>
Which statement is **not** correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 443, 131, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 443, 636, 462]]<|/det|>
The live wire may become loose and touch the metal case.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 470, 131, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 470, 789, 488]]<|/det|>
If the metal case becomes live, the earth wire conducts current to the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 496, 131, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 496, 546, 515]]<|/det|>
The earth wire needs to have a high resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 522, 131, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 522, 792, 540]]<|/det|>
Earthing metal cases helps prevent a person from receiving an electric shock.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 565, 106, 584]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 565, 892, 584]]<|/det|>
What is the function of the split-ring commutator in an electric motor with a single rotating coil?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 594, 133, 613]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 594, 566, 613]]<|/det|>
to enable the motor to function with an a.c. source

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 622, 133, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 622, 596, 640]]<|/det|>
to reverse the current in the coil once every revolution

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 648, 133, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 648, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
to reverse the current in the coil whenever its plane becomes perpendicular to the magnetic field

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 688, 134, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 688, 848, 707]]<|/det|>
to reverse the current in the coil whenever its plane is parallel with the magnetic field

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 416, 740, 435]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 477, 720, 496]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 761, 134, 780]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 761, 312, 780]]<|/det|>
smaller than \(0.35 \text{g}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 787, 138, 806]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 787, 243, 806]]<|/det|>
no change

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 814, 131, 833]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 814, 598, 833]]<|/det|>
changing from smaller to larger than \(0.35 \text{g}\) repeatedly

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 841, 133, 858]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 841, 299, 858]]<|/det|>
larger than \(0.35 \text{g}\)
